Subject: Relevant Paper - Re: New (review) paper on evolving plastic...
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=543004838; y=GNuwSP9DFRQWfVdw9IgHjHYA2jL_fRANdRr1hXFPFIVilfCpvBAomDRIFNoDirAtVTxrJIG247g-2FQ

Hi Oliver,

thanks for your answer and the suggested categories for self-or=
ganization in neural networks. 

It's sometimes not easy to judge whether a=
n observation made by experimentalists is relevant for artificial neuroevol=
ution principles like HyperNEAT or not. For examples pinwheels in the visua=
l cortex seem to emerge even without environmental input but represent a co=
mplex structure which is probably hard to model with CPPNs. But should it b=
e modeled at all? Maybe an adequate solution can be found in another way.

=
With regard to environment-dependent self-organization: I think the hippoca=
mpus is one of those regions that has a similar architecture across species=
 but shows differing properties (e.g. place cells, mechanisms for orientati=
on/navigation, episodic memory) depending on the type of information this s=
tructure has to process. Maybe this is an interesting structure to delineat=
e the phenotypic function of a network (formed by environment-dependent sel=
f-organization) from its general function determined by its genes. 

Best,
=
Martin




--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Oliver Coleman <oliver.coleman@...>=
 wrote:
>
> Hi Martin,
> 
> Apologies for not including references to the r=
elevant papers in the first
> place. :) The two most relevant journal artic=
les (which describe the same
> EA and NN model but include some different t=
asks) are:
> 
>    - Evolution of Cartesian Genetic Programs for Developmen=
t of Learning
>    Neural Architecture (
>    http://www.mitpressjournals.o=
rg/doi/abs/10.1162/EVCO_a_00043 )
>    - Where is the brain inside the brai=
n? (
>    http://www.springerlink.com/content/v0925407k57v4115/abstract/ )
=
> 
> Through communication with Khan I learnt that the initial network stru=
cture
> (placement of neurons in geometric space, etc) is the same througho=
ut an
> evolutionary run (but I think differs between runs), so the evolved=
 genetic
> programs that control the development of the network probably re=
ly on this
> specific initial structure. However the development of the net=
work
> throughout its operational life is also influenced by environmental =
input,
> so it could be said to self-organise with respect to this. As disc=
ussed
> previously on this list it's hard to draw many strong conclusions f=
rom this
> work as it represents a radical departure from anything that has=
 gone
> before and very little analysis was performed of the networks that =
were
> evolved.
> 
> Thanks for the links to the various papers on self-org=
anisation in natural
> neural networks. This is probably nothing new, but i=
t seems that
> self-organisation is used in two ways (which I guess represe=
nt extremes of
> a continuum):
> 
>    - environment-independent, where a s=
tructure (or the overall structure)
>    forms largely due to interactions =
between the neural components alone, and
>    is thus effectively specified=
 by the genome, albeit very indirectly; and
>    - environment-dependent, w=
here the structures that form are heavily
>    influenced by environmental =
signals as well as the interactions between
>    neural components (ie self=
-organising around the input).
> 
> So to answer the question "is there is =
an interpretation of CPPNs in
> HyperNEAT that allows to conclude that self=
-organization must not be
> explicitly modeled in these kinds of networks" =
(in your post that you
> linked to), my guess is that indirect encodings li=
ke HyperNEAT can replace
> the environment-independent type of self-organis=
ation, but that as you move
> towards environment-dependent self-organisati=
on then abstractions of
> development like HyperNEAT can't play as much of =
a role (but perhaps could
> still boost the process by providing some initi=
al structure that is
> fine-tuned by life-time self-organisation). So, my g=
uess is that
> abstractions of development like HyperNEAT are useful, but c=
an only take us
> so far, and that we will need to allow for life-time self=
-organisation
> processes, too.
> 
> Cheers,
> Oliver
> On 17 September 201=
2 18:58, martin_pyka <martin.pyka@...> wrote:
> 
> > **
> >
> >
> > > Perha=
ps we could benefit
> > > from explicitly studying it more in the context o=
f neuroevolution (eg how
> > > can we evolve neural networks that (must) us=
e self-organisation
> > mechanisms
> > > to form the required network struc=
ture or weight pattern; perhaps it
> > > represents a deceptive fitness lan=
dscape like (online) learning). Some of
> > > Khan and Miller's work evolve=
s neural networks that must self-organise
> > due
> > > to starting out wit=
h random structures at the start of every life-time.
> > So
> > > it's grea=
t to have a paper that describes a neural network model that can
> > > lear=
n via an explicit self-organising process.
> >
> > Hi Oliver,
> >
> > can y=
ou tell me, which paper you mean? I also think that self-organizing
> > mec=
hanisms that are influenced by input from the environment are an
> > import=
ant ingredient for the emergence of functions. I think the papers
> > that =
I mentioned in this post
> >
> > http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/neat/me=
ssage/5849
> >
> > point to interesting concepts (e.g. self-stabilizing mec=
hanisms in
> > neurons) that should be further investigated in simulations.=

> >
> > I also enjoyed very much this paper "Evolution of declarative memo=
ry"
> >
> > http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16881079
> >
> > which makes=
 the point that the anatomy of the hippocampus (and therefore
> > probably =
its function) is very well conserved across mammals but depending
> > on th=
e neocortex to which it is attached (e.g. in the fruit bat or
> > chinchill=
a) the observable properties change. So the behavioral function of
> > a ma=
tured neural network should be distinguished from the properties of the
> >=
 network independent from its environment.
> >
> > Best,
> > Martin
> >
> >=
  
> >
>
